review.title: Arabic Language Sentiment Analysis on Health Services
review.abstract: The social media network phenomenon leads to a massive amount of valuable data that is available online and easy to access. Many users share images, videos, comments, reviews, news and opinions on different social networks sites, with Twitter being one of the most popular ones. Data collected from Twitter is highly unstructured, and extracting useful information from tweets is a challenging task. Twitter has a huge number of Arabic users who mostly post and write their tweets using the Arabic language. While there has been a lot of research on sentiment analysis in English, the amount of researches and datasets in Arabic language is limited. This paper introduces an Arabic language dataset which is about opinions on health services and has been collected from Twitter. The paper will first detail the process of collecting the data from Twitter and also the process of filtering, pre-processing and annotating the Arabic text in order to build a big sentiment analysis dataset in Arabic. Several Machine Learning algorithms (Naive Bayes, Support Vector Machine and Logistic Regression) alongside Deep and Convolutional Neural Networks were utilized in our experiments of sentiment analysis on our health dataset.

sections.text: Many users share images, videos, comments, reviews, messages and opinions on various social networks, with Twitter being one of the most popular. Data collected by Twitter is either very unstructured, and extracting useful information from tweets is a challenging task. Twitter has a huge number of tweets that mainly post and write Twitter analyses that use their tweets using the Arabic language. While there is much research on sentimental analyses in English, the amount of research and datasets in Arabic is limited. This paper introduces an Arabic language dataset that contains opinions on health services and was developed by Twitter.The paper will first detail the process of collecting data from Twitter and also the pre-processing of data collected in Arabic to build a large sentimental analysis in Arabic. Several machine learning algorithms (Naïve Bayes, Support Vector Machine and Logistic Regression) alongside Deep and Neural Networks have been used.

sections.heading: A. Data Collection
sections.text: The data was collected from 01 / 02 / 2016 to 31 / 07 / 2016 via Twitter. Initially, the approach was to retrieve tweets that used some general terms related to health, such as "hospital," "clinic," "clinic," "healthcare," etc. However, most tweets found that this was not useful because they did not express opinions on what the purpose of the study was. Alternatively, observing trending hashtags, which are the most popular topics on Twitter at a given time with many users involved, was more useful. Three topics related to health were addressed as trending hashtags and many users shared their opinions on them. They were as follows: # trending hashtags, which are the most popular topic in the processing of Twitter at a given time, involving many users, are about the closure of a private hospital (closure of hospitals). # This topic concerns the closure of a private hospital (closure of hospitals) and the question of who will solve the health problems (solution of health problems).

sections.heading: B. Data Pre-processing and Normalization
sections.text: The number of tweets collected was sufficient to perform the experiment of sentiment analysis, as it contains a variety of words and sentence structures. In contrast, the total number of tweets (126,959 tweets) contained a lot of noisy data, and because the study focused only on positive or negative tweets, all noisy data was removed. (1) Spam tweets, which are tweets that contain advertising or harmful links. (2) Neutral tweets that do not have opinions, such as news tweets. (3) Retweeted tweets that start with "RT" [15]. (4) Duplicated tweets that contain more than one. In addition, as indicated in [15], some pre-processing steps are taken on the remaining tweets by deleting them. (1) Opinions that have nothing to do with health. (2) Twitter usernames, such as the user name @ _ 15, [3].
